description.narrative:
Insatsen bedöms viktig för att främja inklusiv tillväxt i Etiopien, på grund av de flerdimensionella hinder som uppstår i ekonomin till följd av låg och ineffektivt fördelad kapitaltillgång för privat näringsverksamhet i landet. I flertalet studier av tillväxt och fattigdom i Etiopien utmärker sig tillgång till finansiering som ett huvudsakligt hinder för hållbar, dynamisk och inklusiv tillväxt. Detta är fallet i synnerhet för små och medelstora företag (SME), som är mest utmärkande och irrationellt förfördelade vad gäller tillgången till kapital i förhållande till deras potential att växa och skapa arbetstillfällen och förbättrade inkomster för biståndets målgrupper. SME-företagen bedöms vara särskilt viktiga för landsbygdens kvinnor, som idag för sin försörjning ofta är beroende av improduktiv självhushållning eller mikroföretag med begränsad potential för tillväxt, expansion och ökade inkomster.
I den kontexten är en holistisk ansats till finansiering önskvärd, en ansats som i flera avseenden adresseras av IFC (International Finance Corporatiopn) i deras nyskapade finansieringsprogram Ethiopia PSD Initiative Access to Finance (A2F). Trots att IFC:s erfarenheter i Etiopien bara sträcker sig tillbaka till 2008, så har institutionen på dessa år ackumulerat värdefulla insikter och nätverk medan dess globala erfarenheter och resurser för privatsektorutveckling i fattiga länder är mycket omfattande och användbara även i den lokala miljön. Detta skapar förutsättningar för IFC att komma igång relativt snabbt med relevanta operationer inom ett genuint ramverk för styrning och kontroll. En ägarskapsfrämjande efterfrågeledd ansats till bistånd tillämpas samtidigt, där programmets olika delar skapas på direkta önskemål från privat och offentlig sektor.

This programme addresses Access to Finance as a critical bottleneck to pro poor growth in Ethiopia. Via engagements for capital markets development, improved SME banking options, leasing practices, corporate governance practices and credit reporting infrastructure, the programme sets out to create 8 0000 new jobs, lift 30 000 people above the 1.25$/day and improve incomes for the 40% of the population

description.narrative:
All in all, IFC have generated some really interesting results in Ethiopia since our partnership started in 2013. However it seems as if IFC constantly struggle with capacity to build sustainable relationships with local governments (especially in the area of Access to Finance) and manage cross-cutting issues such as sustainability, inclusion, gender and M&E. The IFC pillars are important parts of contributing to the economic reforms initiated by the government of Ethiopia in 2019 to liberalize the business environment and unlock the financial access for SMEs, and the sector. So in a way, Ethiopia is now in par with what the IFC is trying to accomplish through the MDI. For Access to Fincance, while the initial ambition was to target many institutions, most of IFCs work has focused on working with the National Bank of Ethiopia (Central Bank) which is a key player. Sweden pushed for a collaboration with Enat bank as part of this contribution. Sweden supports Enat Bank with a guarantee. This is managed by USAID and Sweden takes part of USAID reporting on the collaboration. The implementation of the Access to Finance (A2F) pillar enabled several reforms despite the COVID-19 crisis during the reporting period. 1. One result is that significant amounts of old and new financing have been recorded in the new collateral registry, and 42 financial institutions are already participating. The number of searches (4,046) has also exceeded the number of new registrations (3,768), which is a positive sign that financial institutions are making appropriate use of the registry’s benefits. 2. The National Bank of Ethiopia has also approved another directive on the codification, valuation, and registration of movable properties as collateral for credit, thus further developing a strong legal basis for secured transactions in the country. This directive builds on the one that operationalizes the movable collateral registry and provides more guidance to the financial institutions on how to leverage movable collateral for the provision of credit. 3. The various program teams also supported clients in their efforts to mitigate the impacts of the crisis. This help included providing Enat Bank with six training courses in finance and marketing that the bank can offer to its female entrepreneurs, via online webinars, to help them mitigate their businesses’ financial risks, maintain their access to finance, digitize their businesses, and navigate the challenges brought about by the pandemic. 4. THe positive part is that NBE has expressed that the IFC support to NBE around strengthening the financial infrastructure in Ethiopia, stating that it lays the foundation to expand access to finance for underserved stakeholders, including MSMEs. In his letter, the vice governor affirms that NBE's partnership with IFC/MDI has resulted in several notable milestones.
Things to be worked on: Given that time has passed, a new revised new A2F Theory of Change (TOC) was shared by the IFC with MDI in 2020 and shows positive changes and reflect a sequentially improved set of versions. 1. The A2F TOC deficiencies The A2F TOC was developed after the associated projects were developed and implemented, not as an evaluation guide. Few defined A2F TOC outcomes are measured in the Progress Report Results Framework The IMPACT measures included in the Progress Report are, in reality, indirect and technically output measures that are weak. For example, the “Sales Revenue (USF$) of intermediaries from CG [Corporate Governance] is not only a count of the degree to which those trained are able to garner income based upon CG advisories, it is a proxy and indirect measure of improved CG. Why not measure CG adoption directly? 2. Gender Equality Mainstreaming A2F: There is a lack of gender equality reporting. There are no results or interventions are included though in the results framework and there is a focus on women trained and number rather than behavioural change of trainings or outcomes.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
